key_insight: Failures on abstract reasoning benchmarks (e.g., ARC, ARC-AGI) are largely driven by lowâ€‘level perception errors rather than core reasoning deficits; when perception is controlled or corrected, model reasoning performance improves markedly.
problem_solved: Determines whether poor performance on abstract-reasoning tasks reflects lack of fluid reasoning or a perception bottleneck, and provides diagnostic tools and interventions to separate the two.
method: Systematic error analysis of vision-language models on ARC and ARC-AGI to categorize failures into perceptual vs. reasoning mistakes.
Ablation and oracle experiments that replace model vision outputs with ground-truth symbolic representations (or simplified inputs) to isolate reasoning capability.
Propose dataset perturbations, evaluation metrics, and perception-focused fixes (e.g., better visual pre-processing or symbolic abstraction) to reveal true reasoning ability.
impact: Re-frames how researchers should interpret reasoning benchmarks: improvements may require fixing perception and evaluation design before attributing errors to reasoning. This guides practitioners to prioritize perceptual modules, benchmark hygiene, and targeted diagnostics.

paper_title: Your Reasoning Benchmark May Not Test Reasoning: Revealing Perception Bottleneck in Abstract Reasoning Benchmarks
paper_authors: Xinhe Wang, Jin Huang, Xingjian Zhang, Tianhao Wang, Jiaqi W. Ma
